messageBody:
On Fri, Sep 9, 2011 at 5:49 AM, Neale Upstone
<neale.upstone@...> wrote:
> I'd say that documentation is part of the product, and therefore should
> start in the same git repo as the Java sources, and be versioned with them.
>
> A simple approach would be to follow Mockito's approach, and make the
> Javadoc the full documentation (at least, I've never needed to look
> elsewhere).

I'm open to any and all improvements to the javadoc that add to
discoverability of features. Mockito is interesting, in that the
release notes, how-to doc, etc., are baked directly into the javadoc.
This didn't immediately appeal to me, because I've found that
long-form text and code samples in javadoc are a pain to maintain,
because of the interaction of HTML and Java syntaxes. Do you know if
the mockito team uses tooling that makes it easier?

> The process would then be a case generating the javadoc into the site
> repo on github, committing and publishing it.
>
> I think this should be as automated as possible.

Yes. Of the code I have personally written for JUnit over the last 8
months, easily over half has been automation of build, release, and
documentation.

> JUnit is a bit off on
> it's founder's XP credentials.

To be fair, to my knowledge, no one's getting paid to work 40-hour
weeks on JUnit, so other XP practices also have to bend. :-)

> , and part of that seems to be an allergy
> to Maven.

I'm not sure about allergy. JUnit predates the first glimmer of maven
by at least three years, and we've been fairly enthusiastic about
community contributions to make working with JUnit and maven easier.

> We should be able to release JUnit from a button on a build
> server :)

Donations toward acquiring cycles happily accepted. ;-)

David Saff

>
>

>> The information about JUnit is across three different places: junit.org, junit.sourceforge.net and github. Additionally some information is missing or very hard to find (new features like rules, current version, how to contribute, ...)
